Show Me No thanks, close See our Privacy Notice Four Scottish regions are in line for 42 hours of heavy rain with the Met Office warning up to a 10cm could fall in some places. Yellow weather warnings have been issued for Perth and Kinross, Stirling, Argyll and Bute, and the Highlands as wet weather sweeps across the country.
The warning comes into force at 6pm on Sunday, December 15 and will last until 12pm on Tuesday, December 17. Forecasters say rain "will become persistent across parts of western Scotland during Sunday" and continue through Monday, December 16 before finally easing on Tuesday.
Between 70mm and 100mm is "likely to fall widely during this period" but over 150mm could fall on "some exposed hills and mountains". Experts warn that rapidly melting of lying snow "will also contribute to any potential impacts".

READ MORE: Will it be a white Christmas? Met Office responds to key snow question with one-word verdict
The Met Office warns that flooding of homes and businesses is "possible" as is interuption to power supplies and other services. Spray on roads will make for tricky driving conditions and bus and train services are likely to be impacted.
Four Scottish regions fall under the yellow weather warning (Image: Met Office) Residents in the warning area are being encouraged to check if their property is at risk of flooding as prepare a flood plan and an emergency flood kit. Travellers should check ahead while households should "consider gathering torches and batteries, a mobile phone power pack and other essential items".
Sepa has yet to issue any flood warnings but that could change over the coming hours. According to WXCharts, stroing winds are also expected through the period with winds of up to 25mph and gusts of up to 40mph.
